title: Thais love to shop abroad
text:
Thais love to shop abroad 23 Jul 2015 at 03:29 102 viewed 0 comments NEWSPAPER SECTION: LIFE | WRITER: KARNJANA KARNJANATAWE - + Thai travellers spend about 44,000 baht by average for an overseas trip and prefer to spend it on shopping, according to the latest Visa Global Travel Intentions Study 2015. 
Conducted in January and February by Millward Brown, global market research and brand consultancy firm, the study had 13,603 participants above the age of 18 across 25 countries, including Thailand. 
It found that Thai travellers were found to spend the most on shopping (31%), dining (22%) then accommodation (10%). Credit card was the preferred payment method for purchases at luxury brand retailers and high-end restaurants, according to Visa Thailand country manager Somboon Krobteeranon. 
"Thais are more inclined to find travel deals that reflect their budgets compared to global travellers. While both spend the majority of their money during the trip, interestingly Thais use credit cards more at destinations," he said. 
Cash might still be king in Thailand, making up about 75% of consumer expenditure, but card payments are gaining ground, as 98% of Thai travellers carry payment cards with them, and almost two-thirds of those who own cards choose Visa as their preferred brand for overseas payments, he said. 
Thai travellers typically prefer regional trips and the top destinations during the past two years are Japan, followed by Singapore, China, Hong Kong then South Korea. They spend about six nights by average per one trip while almost half of the travellers, who travel with companions, preferred to travel with a group of friends or colleagues rather than with their partners and spouses. 
As more Thais travel overseas for leisure, they also intend to spend more while on holiday. They also expect their holiday budget to jump from 44,000 baht on their last trip to 83,000 baht for their next overseas adventure. Thailand's luckiest visitor 
The Tourism Authority of Thailand has joined hands with Thai Airways to give away two economy class tickets to a Frenchman as a celebration of the country's 16 millionth visitor. The lucky man is Lefebvre Quentin who landed at Suvarnabhumi airport on July 15. 
The activity is launched to support the "2015 Discover Thainess" campaign to highlight the endless charm of Thailand, according to TAT deputy governor for Marketing Communications Sugree Sithivanich. 
Quentin said that was surprised to receive two economy-class return air tickets from his home to Thailand along with a five-night accommodation voucher and a "Thailand's Luckiest Visitor" certificate. The tickets will have a validity period of one year. 
According to statistics from the Ministry of Tourism and Sports, the total number of visitors to Thailand rose 30.31% to 15.81 million visitors from Jan 1-July 12 and the average income from international tourists was 741.12 billion baht, or 30.43% higher than the same period of last year. The ministry expects the total visitors this year to reach 28.8 million. Hotels update Evason Hua Hin has partnered with the Matthew Kenney Cuisine from the US to open a culinary academy. The facility offers courses focused on the fundamentals of raw cuisine including the use of whole, organic, unprocessed plant-based foods. As part of an exclusive enrolment package, students are provided with accommodations at the resort. Evason Hua Hin is located about 25km south of Hua Hin. It offers 196 guest rooms, suites and pool villas. Visit www.sixsenses.com/evason-resorts/hua-hin/destination/news/matthew-kenney-culinary . Singapore's Amara Group has opened its first hotel in Thailand. 
Called Amara Bangkok, the hotel is located near two BTS stations — Chong Nonsi and Sala Daeng. It features 250 rooms with sizes ranging from 26m² to 34m², restaurants, a rooftop pool and bar on the 26th floor, grand ballroom, function rooms, executive floors with club lounge and Wi-Fi service. 
Visit bangkok.amarahotels.com . Airlines update Thai AirAsia has signed a Memorandum of Understanding with Bangkok Aviation Centre, Thailand's first private aviation school, to produce 70 commercial licensed pilots a year. 
"Thai AirAsia currently has 450 pilots, comprising 206 captains and 244 first officers. About 40% of our pilots have graduated from the centre," said the airline CEO Tassapon Bijleveld. The aim to have at least 70 new pilots each year will keep up with its plan to add five aeroplanes every year, he said. 
Bangkok Aviation Centre CEO Capt Piya Tregalnon said the school can produce 180 pilots a year. 
"We are fully equipped to train world standard pilots as our training practices, facilities and personnel are all maintained in collaboration with the Royal Thai Air force. We hold the largest share of the pilot training market at approximately 80% and are expanding internationally, especially through the Asian region," he noted. Thai Airways International has joined hands with Airbus to launch the "TG Travel Green Innovation" competition for university students. The competition aims to encourage the students to use their knowledge, abilities and experiences to create environmentally-friendly innovation to benefit the sustainable aviation industry, said Charamporn Jotikasthira, the airline president. 
According to Airbus director of communications-Asia Sean Lee, the competition will also allow the participating students to gain additional experience and knowledge about the industry by offering the opportunity for the winning team to visit Airbus head office and assembly plant in Toulouse, France.
